description: Windows Hello for Business was introduced with the Windows 10 Creators Update. WHfB allows businesses to implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) as part of the Windows client logon process. This series introduces the viewers Windows Hello for Business and then walks you through the entire process of deploying WHfB in a business environment.

name: Windows Hello for Business
subtitle: Windows Hello for Business

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike introduce the viewers to Windows Hello for Business. They discuss the risks associated with standard password usage and explore how Windows Hello for Business can provide a more secure authentication experience.
episodes.title: Concepts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:05.017
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your
host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:05.017 --> 00:00:08.554
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.554 --> 00:00:10.783
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.783 --> 00:00:15.380
>> All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

5
00:00:15.380 --> 00:00:17.570
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:17.570 --> 00:00:19.650
I'm your host Don Pezet.

7
00:00:19.650 --> 00:00:22.360
Here today with a very special
series that we're kicking off,

8
00:00:22.360 --> 00:00:24.550
which is Windows Hello for Business.

9
00:00:24.550 --> 00:00:27.210
And I've got a special guest
here in the studio with us, Mr.

10
00:00:27.210 --> 00:00:30.100
Mike Stephens, who's gonna be helping
us kinda walk through Windows Hello for

11
00:00:30.100 --> 00:00:32.240
Business and see what it can do for us.

12
00:00:32.240 --> 00:00:34.080
Mike, thanks for
joining us in the studios.

13
00:00:34.080 --> 00:00:36.450
>> Thanks for having me Don,
it's a pleasure to be here.

14
00:00:36.450 --> 00:00:40.920
>> And what's on our agenda for
today as far as where to get started?

15
00:00:40.920 --> 00:00:45.090
>> Yeah, so, Windows Hello for Business
is a new thing that we brought out.

16
00:00:45.090 --> 00:00:49.410
And this is going to,
basically it's a password replacement.

17
00:00:49.410 --> 00:00:51.780
We're targeting users on passwords.

18
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:55.020
And so what we're gonna do today
is talk about the concepts

19
00:00:55.020 --> 00:00:56.840
of leading up to Windows Hello.

20
00:00:56.840 --> 00:01:00.845
And why we need Windows Hello
in the infrastructure today?

21
00:01:00.845 --> 00:01:04.650
And the first thing here is to talk
about password itself because you have

22
00:01:04.650 --> 00:01:05.580
a problem.

23
00:01:05.580 --> 00:01:07.830
And when you have a problem,
you need to solve that problem.

24
00:01:07.830 --> 00:01:10.290
So our first thing today is talk
about that passwords are bad.

25
00:01:10.290 --> 00:01:13.140
We've been using passwords for
20 something years.

26
00:01:13.140 --> 00:01:14.650
And there's just the go to.

27
00:01:14.650 --> 00:01:18.410
They're reliable on the sense that
most of use have figured out how to

28
00:01:18.410 --> 00:01:21.080
create a password that's
semi-strong enough.

29
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:23.960
And we just have hard time
getting off of them because so

30
00:01:23.960 --> 00:01:27.080
much of the infrastructure
depends on the password.

31
00:01:27.080 --> 00:01:31.510
And so today what we need to do is
look at why is the password so bad and

32
00:01:31.510 --> 00:01:33.040
why do we need to get off of that?

33
00:01:33.040 --> 00:01:36.570
And so what we really need to do
is break down what a password is.

34
00:01:36.570 --> 00:01:40.350
And at the end of the day,
a password is just a symmetric key.

35
00:01:40.350 --> 00:01:43.773
We type in a password that we know,
so it's like my favorite dog or

36
00:01:43.773 --> 00:01:45.690
something to that effect.

37
00:01:45.690 --> 00:01:50.680
But underneath the covers that password
is hashed with a hashing algorithm or

38
00:01:50.680 --> 00:01:52.880
we use a key derivation like PBKDF2 and

39
00:01:52.880 --> 00:01:57.280
we throw some salt in there, and
maybe some additional entropy.

40
00:01:57.280 --> 00:02:00.140
And the output of that
is basically it's a key.

41
00:02:00.140 --> 00:02:02.820
It's a symmetric key,
it's the secret that I know and

42
00:02:02.820 --> 00:02:05.859
that it's the secret that
the authenticating server knows.

43
00:02:05.859 --> 00:02:09.830
And so that's server is just going to
compare that key to the key I typed

44
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:15.040
in after doing all this computational
stuff and that's how we authenticate.

45
00:02:15.040 --> 00:02:17.780
>> Well, I know you said we've
been using passwords for 20 years,

46
00:02:17.780 --> 00:02:19.860
probably longer for certain things.

47
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:24.780
You watch the old war spy movies where
they had the password response type thing.

48
00:02:24.780 --> 00:02:26.650
That technology's been around a long time.

49
00:02:26.650 --> 00:02:28.700
It's far more advanced
now than it used to be.

50
00:02:28.700 --> 00:02:30.650
You mentioned hashes and
salts and all that.

51
00:02:30.650 --> 00:02:34.430
So, if we have a highly
secured password like that,

52
00:02:34.430 --> 00:02:37.740
why isn't that a good technology for
authentication?

53
00:02:37.740 --> 00:02:41.840
>> So, it's not a good technology for
authentication because there are three

54
00:02:41.840 --> 00:02:45.280
components that we've looked at when
we did Windows Hello for Business.

55
00:02:45.280 --> 00:02:47.850
And one is passwords are phishable.

56
00:02:47.850 --> 00:02:51.620
You can trick somebody into
giving you your password.

57
00:02:51.620 --> 00:02:54.000
The other thing is
passwords are replayable.

58
00:02:54.000 --> 00:02:56.780
The great things about
passwords is thy are portable,

59
00:02:56.780 --> 00:02:58.685
he bad thing is that they are portable.

60
00:02:58.685 --> 00:03:01.390
>> [LAUGH]
>> Once I get one, I can use it anywhere,

61
00:03:01.390 --> 00:03:04.350
and so if I happen to know
Don's password I can go back

62
00:03:04.350 --> 00:03:07.180
to Washington in my office and
I can pretend to be Don.

63
00:03:07.180 --> 00:03:08.510
And it works.

64
00:03:08.510 --> 00:03:12.000
>> At that point the computer has no
way of knowing whether it's you or

65
00:03:12.000 --> 00:03:13.990
me because all it's checking for
is a password.

66
00:03:13.990 --> 00:03:16.310
If you've got my password,
it thinks you're me.

67
00:03:16.310 --> 00:03:17.760
>> Right, it's a single factor.

68
00:03:17.760 --> 00:03:23.160
It's just, I just know that you typed in a
user identity and you typed in a password,

69
00:03:23.160 --> 00:03:26.980
and on the back-end server that's doing
the authentication that password worked.

70
00:03:26.980 --> 00:03:29.810
And so it has no other choice but
to let that user in.

71
00:03:29.810 --> 00:03:31.390
The other thing that it is,

72
00:03:31.390 --> 00:03:35.920
is that we talked about that there
are phishable and what the big thing and

73
00:03:35.920 --> 00:03:39.540
what we've seen in a lot of the TV
today is they're breachable.

74
00:03:39.540 --> 00:03:42.040
Like I said,
in that talk about the password.

75
00:03:42.040 --> 00:03:46.280
When I create a password and we do all
that crypto underneath, that password

76
00:03:46.280 --> 00:03:51.130
still has to be stored on the back end so
it knows how to authenticate me.

77
00:03:51.130 --> 00:03:53.690
And so that's become a very big target.

78
00:03:53.690 --> 00:03:57.270
We've had quite a few things that
we've heard in the news about people

79
00:03:57.270 --> 00:03:59.900
having identity theft because
these breaches on these servers.

80
00:03:59.900 --> 00:04:03.790
So the idea of Windows Hello
is to go to not one factor or

81
00:04:03.790 --> 00:04:08.120
single factor but two factors of
authentication and we'll get into that.

82
00:04:08.120 --> 00:04:11.530
But the point is that two
factors of authentication and

83
00:04:11.530 --> 00:04:15.391
design it in the way to where we can
try to move forward to, non-phishable,

84
00:04:15.391 --> 00:04:19.100
non-replayable and non-breachable.

85
00:04:19.100 --> 00:04:23.590
So with that I want to go into, this is
where we have this whole password thing

86
00:04:23.590 --> 00:04:26.420
and so why I wanted to just
give the users or viewers,

87
00:04:26.420 --> 00:04:31.030
I should say, give the viewers a view of
how passwords are easily breached today.

88
00:04:31.030 --> 00:04:34.320
I have this little PowerPoint animation
here that we can show you here.

89
00:04:34.320 --> 00:04:37.640
And my head's covering up the bottom
there, but we'll get to that.

90
00:04:37.640 --> 00:04:40.060
So here we have this is,

91
00:04:40.060 --> 00:04:44.000
humans are humans, and
we don't like to use complex passwords.

92
00:04:44.000 --> 00:04:47.210
And the problem is,
we end up using the same password over and

93
00:04:47.210 --> 00:04:50.210
over again, because, well, we remember it.

94
00:04:50.210 --> 00:04:54.220
So the problem here is,
I use the password at Bank.com.

95
00:04:54.220 --> 00:04:57.280
I'll also use that same password all
the way through my social media,

96
00:04:57.280 --> 00:04:58.400
maybe some other things, but

97
00:04:58.400 --> 00:05:03.050
then I go to this one obscure sight that
I only need to do one or two things.

98
00:05:03.050 --> 00:05:07.250
But, like a lot of sights, they make me
want to actually sign in with something.

99
00:05:07.250 --> 00:05:10.370
And so, I use the same password,
cuz it's easy to remember.

100
00:05:10.370 --> 00:05:14.880
Well, while we think of our bank being
a very secure and very trustworthy entity.

101
00:05:14.880 --> 00:05:19.380
As we go down this list here on the right
side, we start getting our level of trust

102
00:05:19.380 --> 00:05:23.170
starts to diminish until we
go to Obscure.com, which,

103
00:05:23.170 --> 00:05:26.610
I don't know what they are but there was
something on the website I wanted to see.

104
00:05:26.610 --> 00:05:28.140
And so what happens is,

105
00:05:28.140 --> 00:05:31.970
now the attacker, he's just gonna find
the weakest link in all of these.

106
00:05:31.970 --> 00:05:36.280
He's not gonna go directly to the bank
because banks they are tasked with

107
00:05:36.280 --> 00:05:38.320
making sure that people don't breach.

108
00:05:38.320 --> 00:05:42.847
So what we wanna do then is that
basically the attacker finds Obscure.com,

109
00:05:42.847 --> 00:05:44.550
hacks that password.

110
00:05:44.550 --> 00:05:47.720
And now all of a sudden,
as we alluded to in the intro here,

111
00:05:47.720 --> 00:05:51.372
that attacker can be me anywhere,
all over the place.

112
00:05:51.372 --> 00:05:53.770
Bank.com, Social.com.

113
00:05:53.770 --> 00:05:58.997
And so now, what ends up happening is that
I'm actually compromised at that point and

114
00:05:58.997 --> 00:06:01.465
my identity is gone on multiple sites and

115
00:06:01.465 --> 00:06:04.900
then you just have this
runaway identity problem here.

116
00:06:04.900 --> 00:06:07.820
>> And there's been some high
visibility instances of this lately.

117
00:06:07.820 --> 00:06:11.000
I know Apple was subjected to this
where they were saying there were

118
00:06:11.000 --> 00:06:12.600
hundreds of thousands of
accounts were breached and

119
00:06:12.600 --> 00:06:16.020
it turned out that they themselves
weren't breached, it was other sites and

120
00:06:16.020 --> 00:06:19.660
through password reuse they were able
to compromise those credentials.

121
00:06:19.660 --> 00:06:22.610
So that's a real problem not just for
one company but for

122
00:06:22.610 --> 00:06:24.670
every company,
every organization that is out there.

123
00:06:24.670 --> 00:06:27.650
>> That's a great point, Don, yeah,
I mean the problem we have today

124
00:06:27.650 --> 00:06:32.200
is that we are really,
heavily dependent on passwords today.

125
00:06:32.200 --> 00:06:34.960
And it's a big mountain to move, we've

126
00:06:34.960 --> 00:06:40.110
done several years of investigation on how
can we get to a world without passwords?

127
00:06:40.110 --> 00:06:44.620
And it's not an easy task, it's going
to take a lot of investigation in

128
00:06:44.620 --> 00:06:47.850
each particular enterprise to figure
out how they can move their business

129
00:06:47.850 --> 00:06:50.690
from something that we call weak
credential, which is just user name and

130
00:06:50.690 --> 00:06:55.280
password to a strong credential,
that is, Windows Hello for Business.

131
00:06:55.280 --> 00:07:00.570
So what I wanna do and how is Windows
Hello for Business a strong credential?

132
00:07:00.570 --> 00:07:04.655
Well, let's start with what's
two factor authentication, or

133
00:07:04.655 --> 00:07:07.495
basically multi-factor authentication.

134
00:07:07.495 --> 00:07:09.606
And there's a great document,

135
00:07:09.606 --> 00:07:15.485
NIST SP800-171 has a definition of
what multi-factor authentication is.

136
00:07:15.485 --> 00:07:17.125
But we can simplify it here.

137
00:07:17.125 --> 00:07:19.755
Basically, it's something you have.

138
00:07:19.755 --> 00:07:24.765
It's typically a private key, and
highly recommended that it not be movable,

139
00:07:24.765 --> 00:07:27.855
or secured by some sort
of security device.

140
00:07:27.855 --> 00:07:33.070
A common thing is a smart card, or
perhaps a TPM inside the computer.

141
00:07:33.070 --> 00:07:37.600
The next thing that we have is something
you know and this can be a pin.

142
00:07:37.600 --> 00:07:40.790
And these pins they kind of,
people get, well, pin and password,

143
00:07:40.790 --> 00:07:43.110
that's kind of confusing,
isn't it the same?

144
00:07:43.110 --> 00:07:46.200
And its really not because in these
scenarios where you're doing multifactor

145
00:07:46.200 --> 00:07:50.280
authentication, the pin is actually
entropy, it's not really stored anywhere.

146
00:07:50.280 --> 00:07:55.200
It's basing on the fact that the user
is going to provide this entropy that

147
00:07:55.200 --> 00:07:57.440
has been given during
a time of provisioning.

148
00:07:57.440 --> 00:08:00.744
And it will use that entropy to do
some sort of computation that will

149
00:08:00.744 --> 00:08:04.524
eventually then say, yes,
that is the user, because they knew this.

150
00:08:04.524 --> 00:08:08.430
It doesn't have to compare
The PIN to a stored PIN.

151
00:08:08.430 --> 00:08:09.008
And then,

152
00:08:09.008 --> 00:08:13.540
the final thing that we have here is that
it's something that is a part of you.

153
00:08:13.540 --> 00:08:17.270
In this case, Windows Hello, we have
ability to where we can tie Windows Hello

154
00:08:17.270 --> 00:08:18.800
for Business to use biometrics.

155
00:08:18.800 --> 00:08:22.145
So then you could sign in with your face,
or you can do fingerprint reader.

156
00:08:22.145 --> 00:08:26.835
So it's a very fluid and easy motion,
and it's kind of very futuristic for us,

157
00:08:26.835 --> 00:08:29.965
because you get to go and show all your
relatives how you just sign into your

158
00:08:29.965 --> 00:08:32.555
computer using your face,
or using a fingerprint.

159
00:08:32.555 --> 00:08:34.355
And it's very, very cool.

160
00:08:34.355 --> 00:08:37.845
So, the objective, and
when we did Windows Hello for Business,

161
00:08:37.845 --> 00:08:42.851
was to basically work on those
three pillars of non-fishable,

162
00:08:42.851 --> 00:08:46.790
non-replayable, and
basically non-breachable.

163
00:08:46.790 --> 00:08:50.030
And the way we do that is we start
with the something you have.

164
00:08:50.030 --> 00:08:50.810
Windows Hello for

165
00:08:50.810 --> 00:08:56.160
Business is essentially going to create
a private key in the computer's TPM.

166
00:08:56.160 --> 00:08:59.420
So we support TPM 1.2 and 2.0.

167
00:08:59.420 --> 00:09:03.825
And for older machines we do
support a fallback to software.

168
00:09:03.825 --> 00:09:07.540
Although for enterprises we have group
policies that will actually allow them to

169
00:09:07.540 --> 00:09:10.650
force a hardware one where you
won't fall back to software.

170
00:09:10.650 --> 00:09:13.250
But we have to keep in
mind that everybody's

171
00:09:13.250 --> 00:09:16.130
computer refresh cycle is
not what it's going to be.

172
00:09:16.130 --> 00:09:19.595
>> And I think at this point pretty much
every computer made in the last three to

173
00:09:19.595 --> 00:09:21.198
five years should have a TPM in it.

174
00:09:21.198 --> 00:09:24.551
It's kind of becoming more of a rarity to
find a computer that doesn't have a TPM

175
00:09:24.551 --> 00:09:25.990
integrated, right?

176
00:09:25.990 --> 00:09:29.736
>> Yeah, it just depends on
where you procure your hardware.

177
00:09:29.736 --> 00:09:33.710
TPMs, when you do a build of materials for
these laptops and everything,

178
00:09:33.710 --> 00:09:35.690
these manufacturers are cutting costs.

179
00:09:35.690 --> 00:09:40.090
A TPM might be $0.17, but
that's $0.17 to the bottom line.

180
00:09:40.090 --> 00:09:44.400
So you definitely want to make sure that
when you are looking at Windows Hello for

181
00:09:44.400 --> 00:09:48.370
Business and upgrading your hardware
that you make sure that you call out to

182
00:09:48.370 --> 00:09:53.130
that vendor that you want a TPM,
and preferably you want a TPM 2.0.

183
00:09:53.130 --> 00:09:57.660
I know that Microsoft has recently changed
their hardware guidelines where TPM 2.0

184
00:09:57.660 --> 00:10:02.530
is what we are recommending for
Windows Logo PCs right now.

185
00:10:02.530 --> 00:10:06.060
And TPM 2.0 is just
a better version all out.

186
00:10:06.060 --> 00:10:11.120
It doesn't lock out as easy, it has better
performances, it supports more crypto.

187
00:10:11.120 --> 00:10:13.160
So, it's just a better overall thing.

188
00:10:13.160 --> 00:10:15.870
But we know that it's gonna
be a gradual movement

189
00:10:15.870 --> 00:10:18.220
before you get from TPM 1.2 to 2.0.

190
00:10:18.220 --> 00:10:22.980
But most PCs in an enterprise
will have a TPM 1.2.

191
00:10:22.980 --> 00:10:24.380
There's already things that use it.

192
00:10:24.380 --> 00:10:29.170
Like right now BitLocker needs a TPM 1
to use that, and there are other things

193
00:10:29.170 --> 00:10:33.410
that is more and more prevalent where
TPMs are just being used more and more.

194
00:10:33.410 --> 00:10:37.550
So that's not really a hard thing, but we
need to have that TPM because what do we

195
00:10:37.550 --> 00:10:41.910
want, we wanna have that thing that you
know, or sorry, that thing that you have

196
00:10:41.910 --> 00:10:45.015
is gonna be a private key,
that private key is generated in a TPM.

197
00:10:45.015 --> 00:10:48.570
TPMs have all this crypto built into them,

198
00:10:48.570 --> 00:10:52.700
so they can do random number generator,
they do all this stuff inside the TMP.

199
00:10:52.700 --> 00:10:54.930
And they generate a key.

200
00:10:54.930 --> 00:10:57.950
And that key is then
wrapped with a key that's

201
00:10:57.950 --> 00:11:01.210
burnt into the TPM at
the time of manufacturing.

202
00:11:01.210 --> 00:11:05.310
And that key is different for
each TPM that's manufactured.

203
00:11:05.310 --> 00:11:07.760
And so
TPMs don't really have a lot of storage.

204
00:11:07.760 --> 00:11:11.760
So what happens is is that key
is wrapped with that unique key

205
00:11:11.760 --> 00:11:16.450
that's burnt into the TPM at the time of
manufacturing and then persisted to disk.

206
00:11:16.450 --> 00:11:20.540
And so that way, even if you were to get
that key and move it laterally one way or

207
00:11:20.540 --> 00:11:24.620
another, it's not gonna work because
you need to feed it into the TPM that

208
00:11:24.620 --> 00:11:25.540
actually created it.

209
00:11:25.540 --> 00:11:29.490
And so that's where we can get this
where we don't have lateral movement of

210
00:11:29.490 --> 00:11:32.120
the actual something you have.

211
00:11:32.120 --> 00:11:36.310
The next thing that we're gonna
talk about is is that the something

212
00:11:36.310 --> 00:11:37.480
you know which is the PIN.

213
00:11:37.480 --> 00:11:42.120
As I mentioned, that's entropy, and
so we don't persist the PIN anywhere.

214
00:11:42.120 --> 00:11:47.350
And so that way, if that PIN is ever
entered wrong, then it's not gonna work.

215
00:11:47.350 --> 00:11:50.070
Because what happens is is the way to

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss the necessary steps for an organization planning to deploy Windows Hello for Business. The discuss how to select between a hybrid or on-premises deployment. They also discuss how to select an appropriate trust model for your deployment. At the end of the episode, Mike describes the high-level steps for building a deployment strategy.
episodes.title: Planning the Deployment

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike demonstrate how to prepare the Microsoft Active Directory for a Windows Hello for Business deployment. Mike demonstrates how to extend the AD schema and then creates the necessary users and groups to support the final deployment.
episodes.title: Preparing the Active Directory

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss configuring a Microsoft public key infrastructure (PKI) to support Windows Hello for Business. They discuss some of the certificates that are required, and then demonstrate configuring certificate templates to provide them.
episodes.title: Preparing the PKI

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike continue discussing the configuration of a Microsoft PKI. In particular, they demonstrate using a group policy object (GPO) to enable certificate auto-enrollment and allowing users to receive the required certificates. This is the final step in configuring the PKI to support Windows Hello for Business.
episodes.title: Preparing the PKI Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike discuss implementing Active Directory Federation Services to support Windows Hello for Business. Specifically, Mike demonstrates installing Active Directory Federation Services and then assigns a web server certificate using the template created in the previous episode.
episodes.title: Preparing AD Federation Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike complete the configuration of Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS). Mike demonstrates how to use Group Managed Service Accounts to better secure ADFS. Finally, Mike demonstrates configuring the Device Registration Service (DRS)
episodes.title: Configuring AD FS and DRS

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike walk the viewers through configuring the Registration Authority to support Windows Hello for Business. Mike explains how to leverage group managed service accounts and custom certificate templates. Finally, Mike uses the certutil command to modify the certificate template to suite Windows Hello for Business.
episodes.title: Configuring the Registration Authority

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike go through the steps required to verify the Registration Authority is properly configured and that certificate auto enrollment is properly issuing certificates to the ADFS service.
episodes.title: Configuring the Registration Authority Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike perform a recap of all the components configured so far and how they work together to support user authentication. Mike then goes on to create the DNS records and internet zone settings to complete the configuration of the Registration Authority.
episodes.title: Configuring the Registration Authority Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike explain how you can leverage Azure MFA to power your on-premises deployment. Mike then walks the viewers through installing the pre-requisites for Azure MFA.
episodes.title: Prepare an Azure MFA Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike explain how the MFA User Portal can be configured to support Windows Hello for Business. Mike then walks the viewers through configuring the pre-requisites in preparation for installing the MFA User Portal.
episodes.title: Preparing the MFA User Portal

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike walk the viewers through the process of installing and configuring the Azure MFA server. Mike then moves on to enable users to access the MFA service and forcing the MFA server to synchronize.
episodes.title: Configuring the MFA Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike walk the viewers through the process of installing and configuring the Azure MFA user portal. Mike demonstrates how to create a user portal configuration file and creates the appropriate DNS records to support the portal.
episodes.title: Installing the User Portal

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike wrap up the technical configuration of Windows Hello for Business. Specifically, Mike demonstrates how to tell the Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS) to use the Multi-factor Authentication (MFA) server. Mike shows how to create a custom ADFS adapter and implements it using Windows PowerShell.
episodes.title: Connecting the AD FS to the MFA Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike walk the viewers through the final steps of configuring Windows Hello for Business. Mike discusses some of the group policy object settings that can be used to deploy Windows Hello to your end users. Finally, he creates and deploys the required GPO.
episodes.title: Configuring Group Policy

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Mike conclude deploying Windows Hello for Business. Mike demonstrates the user experience by logging in as a user with Windows Hello for Business enabled. He shows the dual-factor login process and wraps up the Windows Hello for Business deployment.
episodes.title: Deploying and Testing
